title: Dwayne Haskins not assured of Redskins starting job after rocky debut
text:
Washington Redskins rookies Jimmy Moreland and Dwayne Haskins walk off the field together after Sunday's 24-3 to the Giants. (Toni L. Sandys/The Washington Post)

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Dwayne Haskins strode to the podium in the bowels of MetLife stadium after making his NFL regular season debut Sunday and appeared slightly annoyed. He banged a bottle of water on the wood structure a couple times without anywhere to put it, and his thumb anxiously tapped the lectern.

This was a moment he had waited for since childhood, but it wasn’t a happy one. The Redskins were throttled, 24-3, by the division rival New York Giants, the team he grew up admiring, and the subpar performance of starter Case Keenum necessitated Haskins’ NFL initiation. Yes, the 15th overall pick wants to play, but he doesn’t wish ill will toward Keenum. And the rookie certainly doesn’t want to lose games, regardless of how he gains his opportunities.

“I had a whole bunch of emotions in my head,” Haskins said. “I just wanted to win the game, and we didn’t. It is what it is. On to the next week. … I hate losing, I really do. We’re going to keep getting better, and that’s not happening again.”

The question becomes when Haskins will get his next opportunity, as Coach Jay Gruden was unwilling to name a starter for next week’s game against the New England Patriots after the loss.

“We’ll worry about tomorrow, tomorrow,” Gruden said brusquely. “Then I’ll reevaluate everything. … He’s got to earn that right [to start] first. I don’t care where you’re drafted, when you’re drafted, you need to earn that. He’s got to come in here and perform when he’s asked to perform. If I feel like he gives us the best chance to win against New England, I’ll put him in there. … You’re just not handed the keys because of where you’re drafted.”

[The key moments from Redskins' 24-3 loss to the Giants]

Haskins was drafted to be the future franchise quarterback, but no one knew when that day would come. He competed for the starting job in training camp but clearly wasn’t ready to be the opening-week starter. Fans called for Haskins to start as the team fell to 0-3, particularly with other first-round quarterbacks, such as Daniel Jones of the Giants, starting throughout the league, but Gruden resisted.

After Keenum struggled early Sunday — including overthrowing a wide-open Trey Quinn for a potential touchdown on the first snap of the game and throwing an interception two plays later — Gruden relented and went to his young signal-caller.

Offensive coordinator Kevin O’Connell had given Haskins a warning early in the second quarter that his time may be coming, and he injected some life into the offense upon entering the game. He connected on his first two passes, including a third-down conversion, and his 14-yard scramble set up first-and-goal from the one-yard line. Haskins nearly had his first touchdown pass, but he threw wide and outside to an open Vernon Davis on third down, and the team settled for a field goal.

He struggled in the second half, as the team was shut out, and he finished 9 for 17 passing with 107 yards and three interceptions. He was sacked twice.

“I thought he did provide a spark,” running back Adrian Peterson said. “He came in and did a good job. Of course, he had interceptions, but that’s things he can tweak. … Of course things could have been better.”

Gruden will now have to decide whether he wants to switch to Haskins on a full-time basis and give him the first-team reps in practice. The coach also has the option of going back to Keenum, or calling upon Colt McCoy. The veteran returned to practice last week after dealing with complications stemming from last season’s broken leg, and is expected to be healthy enough to play against the Patriots.

The 22-year-old Haskins did have some positives, including showing some good mobility and earning praise from Gruden for his pocket presence, but there’s plenty he needs to improve.

“I just knew that my time would be coming and when the day comes, that I’d be ready for it,” Haskins said. “I didn’t execute the way I wanted to, but the good thing about it is that it hurts, and there [are] going to be brighter days tomorrow. … I want to win. I’m going to win. Whatever it takes to win, we will do that. … We’re going to change that and win some games. I’ll be here for a while, so get used to seeing me smile up here.”

Vontaze Burfict ejected for late, helmet-to-helmet to hit

For better or worse: Two Bills fans got married at halftime on the 50-yard line
description: Washington’s first-round pick was intercepted three times during Sunday’s loss to the Giants. Coach Jay Gruden wouldn't commit to him as next week's starter.
authors: Kareem Copeland Is The Post'S Washington Redskins Beat Writer. He Previously Covered The Utah Jazz
